Main flavours are cereals, honey and alcohol with a touch of caramel and some aromatic grassy and floral hops with no bitterness at all.  Sweetness level is average.  Enjoyable well put together beer with a nice mouthfeel.  Despite all its qualities I found it rather simple although the aromatic floral hops kept me entertained.  The foundation of a great triple is there and it could acheive that status if given a little more complexity (spicy twist, fruity notes, something...).  Still this was very good, basic, reliable and effective, this beer is to tripels what steak & fries is to fine cuisine.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a huge moslty lasting creamy white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts, fruits, orange, and hops. Creamy palate.

Bottle. Murky gold color like an unsettled wort.  Frothly white head that isnt going anywhere.  Carbonation is there, but hard to see through the cloudiness.  Aroma is packed with honey, nutmeg, orange peel, an other assorted spices.  A tingly flavor leaning toward citrus and nutmeg but a fair amount of hops to balance the sweet.  What your left with is a warm alcohol finsih like a good brandy.  Admirably light palate handling the 9% alcohol with ease.  A quencing brew that will warm you up and make you smile.
On Tap @Toronado on 3/30/07.  Pours straw with a thin white head.  The aroma was sweet with candied sugar.  The taste was also sweet but also slightly hoppy.  Very good tripel.

Poured into Trappist glass.   Deep gold color, lacing present.   Well formed slightly off-white one finger head that quickly dissipates.  Perfumy aroma.  Slightly malty flavor with hops dominating.  Medium bitterness.  I dont notice the alcohol.  Not bad, but Ive had better tripels.

On tap at the Sharp Edge Creekhouse. Nice tripel that I have been waiting a while to try. Pour was a cloudy gold with a  finger head. Aroma was sweet and yeasty. Taste was strong and different than Ive had for a tripel. Tasted like a yeasty dry Belgian with crushed up Fruity Pebbles in it yet had some citrus and lemon in the background. Perfumy in the mouth and in the swallow. This is a unique beer.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This beer looks like a brick of gold.  Its a bit hazy and has a small white head.  The aroma is juicy and carries something herbal and something barn-like.  It hits the tounge with a juicy sizzle.  Its fluffy and perhaps a bit alkaline.  The flavor is malt, citrus... Its tangy, sour and plenty bitter.  Lemon peel is the flavor that dominates.  A good tripel.

do any of the beers on tap at Eulogy Belgian Tavern in Philly disappoint? apparently not. beautiful murky blood-orange egg-yoke body with a tiny white fizz rim head. smells of grass and citrus. tastes slightly bitter, light-citrus hops. becomes more bitter toward the end. hints of grapefruit. very tasty.

Bottle. 11.2 FL. OZ. Pours a golden brown color with a very active head that starts out big then quickly diminishes to almost nothing.   Strong aroma of raisin and butterscotch.  Light to medium bodied with some lively carbonation. Very sweet flavor that covers the alcohol nicely.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2007 Bottle. Sweet malt nose with some floral hop notes. Hints of figs, cinnamon, sour apples, some sourdough background. Beautiful cloudy orange with a frothy heavy white head. Leaves some huge lacing. Creamy palate, nice and smooth start to finish. Not too complex flavor, but still really nice. Well-balanced yeasty sourness with some subdued sweetness. Tinge of alcohol

Aroma:brown sugar,caramel,fruity....
Appearance:light hazy gold,huge white head.Good carbonation.....
Flavor:caramel-brown sugar,floral,light alcohol,banana....

12 oz bottle. Pours a beautifully murky honey colored body with a decent thick white head of micro-bubbles that leave leggy lacing.  Fairly active carbonation.  The aroma of sugar and caramel combined with a hint of dough keeps this abbeys nose true to style.  The taste starts dull for the first second, with only an earthy tone that explodes in to a bloom of floral and citrus flavor with a wonderfully malty and alcohol-laden finish thats accompanied by a decent bubbly mouthfeel that isnt to astringent to the palate.

750 ml bottle. Shiny gold body with abundant carbonation and a big, foamy white head.  Aroma has sweet floral tones plus fresh bread and candy corn notes.  Semi-sweet flavor with pleasant yeast characters, a nice rounded malt profile, and light bitterness.  Very elegant and pleasing without any wrong notes.

330 ml bottle.  Golden pour with very fluffy white head that lasted forever.  Very malty aroma with ripe banana and bread.  Flavor is matly as well.  Lots of yummy yeasty flavor too.  Nice pepper finish and touched of alcohol.  Very good tripel.
Poured a cloudy yellow with a huuuge white, rocky yet smooth head.  All the triple aromas are there (coriander, citrus).  Alcohol on your throat going down.  Comfort  beer.

Had high expectations for this one. Golden pour like most Belgian ales. Aroma was fruity. I detected some strawberry and my buddy detected slight hints of green apple. Quite a bit of head but quickly diminishes. This is one of my favorites.

Poured from a 750ml bottle into a tulip glass, but not all at the same time. Light golden with a medium white head. Aroma was of spice, malt and a touch of banana. The taste started out with a touch of sweetness and malt with some spice and turned dry as it warmed. there was a noticeable alcohol bite. I have a bit of a sweet tooth and really like the other Gouden offerings for this reason. I was a bit disappointed in this and rate the ambrio, classic and Cuvee Van De Keizer among my favorites, but this one is lagging for me.

Pour is a golden with a super huge white head.  Aroma is lots of yeast and cloves with some fruits showing up.  Flaovr is a bit lower than the aroma but there are some sour fruit and a bit of honey.  So-so for the style.

About 5 years old. Aromas of light caramel, malt and some spice. Hazy, light ripe apricot color with a  head that did not hang around. Starts with ripe fruit flavor, moves to Belgian candy, then on to spicy malt, ending a bit hoppy with balancing caramel / lightly roasted maltiness. Very lightly spritzy carbonation. Most everything about this tastiness is that its light. No one thing unreasonably dominates.

Pours a nice slightly hazy golden color.  nice slightly hopped arome with hints of candi sugar, ripe citrus fruit and slight spice.  the flavor is great with a nice tripel sweetness and spice, but there is a nice hoppiness from the dry-hopping.  I love this freaking beer.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Competent but wont blow you away. Blond ale-like with sweet malts and hints of corriander. Eats up the 9% with ease. (e2.60 on tap at Kulminator).
Delicious triple.  Nice white head, beautiful lacing, Nose has anise notes.  Taste is a little sweet for me, but delicious.  The color is amber with a nice cloud.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Golden muddy coloration. High/average carbonation. Excellent cream. This beer has an uneven taste, maybe notes of honey and orange................................PORTUGUÊS: Coloração golden turva, com coisas acontecendo... Carbonatação média/alta. Ótimo creme. Essa ceva tem um gosto ímpar, que pra mim se deve às notas de mel e laranja.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2008 Coloração dourada turva, com coisas acontecendo... Carbonatação média/alta. Ótimo creme. Essa ceva tem um gosto ímpar, que pra mim se deve às notas de mel e laranja.

On tap at Great Dane  - Hilldale.  Pours a beautiful hazy golden with a full head.  Fruity nose followed the same in the mouth.  Pears, green apples, apricots, cardamon.  Slightly sour. but well balanced overall.  A bit of yeast and sourdough.  Nice.
Bottle from World of Beer in Clearwater - this is a very delicious blond beer which I was expecting - very sweet malty - balanced spices and very good through and through

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2008 Golden honey colored with a HUGE white dimpled head.  Aroma is faintly sour with a sweet maltyness. Taste is rather mild, with no biting spice or cloying sweetness. Interesting grape skin flavor in the finish, and warms to apricot aroma and taste. An excellent tripel. $8/750ml

Draught at reBar.  Hazy amber with a frothy white head.  Pronounced yeast aroma, like half baked bread, with light fruity notes--banana, apple, pear, citrus.  Off-sweet bready malt flavor with some mild yeasty notes.  Fruity and well rounded.  Subtle spices-not  overpowering or too peppery.  Medium to full body with a mostly smooth mouthfeel--fine light carbonation.  Very enjoyable.

Cloudy yellow gold hue, with a rocky white head, leaving nice laces, yeasty fruity nose of citrus fruits, with pineapple, ripe apples, with a spicy coriander accent, with a grapefruit floral hops and a sweet honeyish pale malt aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, sweet candied lemon citrusy character, with flowery hop, releasing some grapefruit flavors, with a mellow honeyish warmth alcoholic mouthfeel, with coriander spiciness, ripe apples and pears fruitiness, and sweet pale malt, leading towards a faint dry hops bitterness, and an alcoholic warmth finih.

Clear golden color, moderate white foamy head.  Sweet malty and yeasty aroma--presence of spices (clove, coriander), flowers, candy sugar, and perhaps a hint of pineapple and banana.  Flavors are a nice balance of sweet malts, spices, and hops.  The bitterness of this beer does not allow the sweetness to run rampant.  This is a nice, well-balanced tripel.  The mouthfeel is soft and a bit sticky, but is dried up nicely by the astringency of the hops.  Certainly worth drinking again, and definitely lived up to my expectations.  I havent yet had a "bad", (or even "average") Gouden Carolus beer.  Cant wait to have more of these...
Bottle. Poured a golden color with a 3 finger head very carbonated. Aroma of clove and roses. Taste of citrus and very sweet.

750.  Very hazy golden/light brown with a medium to large off white head.  Aroma is malty and sweet with a touch of spices.  Taste is sweet unattenuated caramel malt, covers up almost all the spice and yeast characteristics of this beer.  I have no idea of what happened with this one, considering the other ratings.  wow, what a dissapointment.

750ml bottle.

Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow, with a thin quarter inch head that slowly fades away to nothing, leaving behind only small traces of lacing.

Smell; very yeasty, with bananas and a little citrus. Theres also some nice bready malts with a touch of peppery spices.

Taste; as with the aroma, the yeasts are right up front in the flavor of this one. The fruits are present with bananas and some citrus, with a little bit of peaches thrown in. Even with those fruits, they dont become overwhelming, which I sometimes have a prolem with. Some candied sugar and bread dough malts come out in the finish. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, and seems to fit this beer very well, with a very nice drinkability
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
Nice golden color, surprisingly clear, with a very thick layer of soft cream-colored suds. Beautiful lace clings to the glass as I savor every sip.

Bold sweet malt with honey, alcohol, a little peppery spice, and a faint bubblegum taste. Finishes on the dry side, with the alcohol being dominant. Then some residual sweetness.

As I pour the third glass (my wife had the second glass) the color is more murky and amber from the yeast I stirred up. I swear there is more alcohol in the flavor now than before.
Bottle, 33 cl. Hazy golden with white head. Sweet and tart aroma with  candy, yeast, some spiciness. Interesting flavors. Fast, sweet, spicy,  dry finish. Taste the strong alcohol.
Bottle, thin creamy off white head. Fruity and malty aromas amd sweet malty taste. A bit sweety for  my liking but not a bad triple.

Interesting brew. Cloudy dark orange color. Aroma and flavor both are strongly reminding me of wine or old port. A bit sweet and a small amount of bitterness too in the flavor. Overall a nice and interesting brew.

0.33l bottle at home. Yellow with thin white head. Some lacing remained on the glass. Spicy aroma with hint of orange and alcohol. Thick smooth mouthful. Taste is sweet at the beginning and spicy bitter at the end. Long warm feeling after you have a sip. Good triple.

2006 bottle shared by tpkenned. Hazed, buffed and pale yellow in color with a thick, tall and sudsy white head. Sweet, soapy lemon shine aroma is aided by shrocked lemon rind shavings, lemon-pistachio buttercream, coriander, vanilla beans and banana taffy. Sweet, creamy bananas meld with a lemon saltwater taffy character. Fluffy effervescence is well met by the dry, lemon buttered sourdough. Chewy sorghum and a sweetened papaya-banana smoothie characteristic eventually spinn into a dry, tropical and citric outtake. Full-bodied, followed by a sharp, dry cotton bitterness. Marigolds with a creamy nectar blanket envelops the palate with a vanilla mint creamy glossiness at the end.

The 11.2 ounce bottle poured a slightly hazy golden amber beverage with an ample frothy white head that was mostly lasting and left great lacing on the glass. The first aroma that hit me was bubble gum and then came a sweet fruitiness accompanied by pepper, coriander and honey ... very yummy. The body was medium with a very active carbonation level and a slight syrupy texture. The flavor starts out moderately sweet with honey, fruits and spices. This sweetness stays consistent through the long finish and is completed by a big alcohol warmth in the chest.
Bottle. Orange/golden colour with an off-white head.Aroma is yeast, orange, fruit, spices. Flavour is yeast, fruit, sweet, apple, spices.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2009 Bottle, 75cl corked. Two years past BB-date. It pours a slightly hazy, sparkling golden body with a gigantic creamy off-white head. Fine lacings left. Slightly cellary or corked on the nose, with pale malt, fruityness, some citrus hints and spices and a little piney note. Well hidden alcohol. Warming, effervescent and full-bodied. Slightly cellar-like flavor too, with citrusy, piney hops, some bitterness balancing the white sugar sweetness, and a herbal touch. Pale malts as well. Also something reminiscent of dried apricots. Lasting finish with good warmth and a fine bitterness. Its probably better when fresh, but the two extra years of cellaring sure as hell didnt ruin it. Rating: 7-4-8-4-16-3.9. (090410)Bottled, 0.33. A cloudy, orange beer with lots of floaties, and a huge, dense, lasting off-white head. Nice, sweet nose with oranges and spices. Sweet flavor with orange-peel, both fresh and dried fruits and black tea. Fullbodied, quite gassy beer, almost sticky mouthfeel. The finish is long, with bitterness, warming alcohol and spices. I love Het Anker. (061130)
Cloudy orange pour with moderate head.  Aroma is sweet with a bit of orange and citrus.  Flavor is smooth and a bit fruity.  Decent dry finish.  Pretty good.

Pours a very hazy dark yellow orange color with a medium amount of froathy white head.  Aroma is very sweet and fruity, passion fruit, grapefruit, and banana.  Flavor is very smooth and sweet, honey and banana and apple and orange.  Finish is dry but still sweet and nectary.  Overall, an alltime favorite.  Wish i had more.

[bottle] Light golden in color, with a foamy white head. Sweet fruity aroma, with a bit of alcohol present. Flavors are fruity, like peach and pear, with yeast and some sweetness towards the end. Finishes pretty dry, with some spice.

Pours a golden color with a medium sized white head. Interesting beer that has hints of honey, apple, and pineapple in the aroma and taste but finishes quite dry. Very fizzy on the tongue. Good stuff.
Bottle @ Bens place. Yeasty aroma with orange, apples and yeast. Looks like peach nectar! Small white head. Anis, (fermented) fruits in the flavour, bitter yeastyness in the finish.

Bottled(330ml). Shared with Doggythedog at the Hopdevil in Zagreb
Like other Gouden Carolus beers very nice brew. Golden coloured, small white head, fruity coriander nose. Aroma is yeasty, fruity and spicy with mild notes of honey and vanilla.
Thick firm head, golden orange body, slightly cloudy. Peach(baked), citrus, and sweet malt nose. Very fruity, yet hint of malt character. Light alcohol presence. Very nice finish.

Poured a nice golden body on top of which perched a medium sized white head that went away fast. The nose is lovely... bubblegum, banana, really perfumey, malt, some coriander. The taste is again fruity, coriander,honey,  oranges, apple, candy, yeast... Lovely. Definitely not a by the book triple... Damn I love this brewery.

Bottle. Slightly cloudy light golden color. Stable and nice big white head. What a Triple this is. Aroma is banana, orange, yeast and some notes of spice as well. What an array flavors with hints of honey without getting to sweet. Defiantly full bodied with a full sweetness to it with some light bitterness. Would really like to compare this to Tripel Karmeliet one day, think it is right op there next this it. Defiantly one of the evenings big surprises.

A light floral smell yet slightly skunky when poured.  A nice medium white head that settled quickly.  A nice hazy gold look and full flavored for its class. Slightly bitter after taste.  All around solid beer.
At first I thought I smelled a skunk, but that went away leaving a nice floral armoa.  The palate is very evervesant.  Looks a golden yellow.  Overall a very nice beer
A blond-amber coloured beer with a fluffy white head. The aroma is sweet and malty. A sweet and fruity taste. The flavour is a bit too sweet for me. (Bottle 33cl aged 2.5 years)
Pours bright gold into a tulip.  Bright white micro head slowly recedes.  Sweet raisin aromas.  Dry and tart with a lasting bitter/sweet finish.
Smells like a triple with just a little extra malt. Pretty dry, w/some noticeable finishing hops. Another nice beer, no. 27, for the list.
Had it for first time in Boston. Had a nice strong aroma. Very fruity tase.
On tap. Hazy gold, thin white head. Aroma is fruit, wheat, spices. Flavor is fruit, wheat, slightly sour and musty.

750 ml bottle.  Pours out a brownish yellow color with a white head that goes away pretty quickly.  Smell is spicy, hoppy, and malty.  Some sugar and lemon is also apparent.  Taste is smooth with no trace of the alcohol being evident at all.  There is also a nice lemony flavor to it.  Pretty good stuff actually.  Not too hoppy, which is good because extremely hoppy tripels are not my thing.

330 bottle, from BevMo LaJolla.  Pours mostly clear, lemon-golden color with a large white head.  Aroma of sugar cookies, peach, lemon, yeast, spring flower soap, wheaty notes, vanilla and  floral hops.  Flavor is sweet, sweet, candy sugar, and lemon, clover, tart floral notes, apricot, with a bready character, the signature GC yeast and a pleasant hop finish.  Medium body and smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 750mL, no date.  Pours a clear golden with gigantic, frothy white head.  Aroma has some yeast, spicy hops, banana, candy sugar, and light oranges.  Flavor a lot more stale fruity than I had anticipated, with a nice, dry finish.  Overall taste leans much more to sweetness, with some raisins and oranges being up front.  Thick mouthfeel, still fairly carbonation despite everything that went to its head.  There is a little warming in the back of the throat from the ETOH.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Huge head at pouring. Lasted a LONG time in the glass. Nice golden color. Yeasty/wheaty flavor. Slight alcohol aftertaste. Cloudy consistancy.

This beverage pours a slightly cloudy, very light coppery yellow color, with a tall, foamy head that sticks around. Its got a crisp, sweet smell of candy and malt, with spice and citrus in the background. The carbonation is abundant and moderately prickly, but the beer is heavy in the mouth, and the carbonation is welcome to balance that. The beer has a mostly sweet flavor, but its more complex than my other recent adventures, with hints of banana, herb, spice and citrus. Sips finish pleasantly dry with an alcohol warmth coming back for the last word. Theres a slightly bitter aftertaste, but its not at all unpleasant.  Overall?  Yum!

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2014 1) Smouldering bottle, elusive herbal nose. Misty apricot tulip with rocky froth that goes the distance. One sniff of this and Im tripping across the cobbles, goggling skyward at the floodlit majesty of the Belfort and piddling against a church. Make no mistake, this is dangerous. But a beauty. Devilishly smooth malty booze and dry yeasty spice. Mysterious woody perfume. Distilled Orval with a wormwood chaser. Vague glowing numbness in the toes. Green Fairy shandy. Going for a lie down now.   
2) September 2009. Blind re-rate. Dusky apricot under a mad rippling billow. Shit,you could float a Euro on that. Ripe hum of mango, pineapple, orange peels, Cointreau and fenugreek;. big gust of Deep Heat once the heads gone. Sort of inscrutable Belgian that has me rummaging in the spice cupboard for metaphors. Tea, bittering herb, marmalade, juniper and booze . Incredible continents of lace at 9%. Indiscreet alcohol and spiciness. Great shit.
584716.

Just had this beer for the first time on draft a few weeks ago.  Strong aroma of spices and nice head.  Definite complex flavors but could pick up some citrus tones.  Great mouthful and leaves you with a clean finish.  Definite recommend

Draught at Belgobaren Sthlm. Clear, deep golden. Small head. Aroma is estery to the point of being harsh and "solventy". Taste is a bit thin and I think this beer really suffers from not being bottle conditioned.. going to try and find a bottle instead.

Hazy dull yellow with white head. Pleasant sweet and tart, musty aroma with hard candy, yeast, banana, some spiciness. Sharp in flavor with a balancing alcohol note. Very interesting flavors. Slightly floral, a bit earthy, somewhat herbal, with citrus highlights. Spritzy mouthfeel. Fast, spicy finish.

Pours with a clear, rich, concentrated gold color and is topped by an easily three-finger thick, frothy, light tan colored head that leaves some lacing on the sides of the glass.  The aroma is quite herbal; perhaps a mix of fermentation character, hops and even a touch of grassy malt.  Notes of vanilla peak through a base of dry weeds (which give this some sharp biting notes), .  There is a nice aromatic note of both sweet and toasty malt here that has vague nuances of butterscotch, a just lightly malty caramel note, some dry soda cracker notes, and the aforementioned grassy grain character.  There is a touch of higher alcohols in the nose, which only seem to accentuate that sharp, sort of weed-like herbal note that seems to be the most dominant note.

Sharp up front with a herbal astringent note, but the beer immediately softens up a bit with a sweet malt character.  Notes of honey are certainly in evidence and mix quite well with the herbal notes; the combination makes me think of some sort of greenish wild flower nectar.  This beer has a way of lightly sticking to the palate, letting one no that this is not a beer to take lightly, though it certainly drinks a bit lighter than its alcohol content might suggest.  Back to that sharpness, it seems to be a combination of higher alcohols and some phenolic notes, neither of which are out of control and in fact add a touch of balance to the sweetness that might otherwise be dominating.  Speaking of phenolics there is a definite note of clove here, which tends to accentuate the sweet malt.  There are also some noticeable fruit notes here, predominantly pear, green apple, and tart plum.

This is an interesting beer; sweet yet astringently dry at times; palate sticking, yet light enough to be quaffable.  There is definitely enough sharp rough edges here to balance the sweet malt and fruit notes.  At times this beer is incredibly enjoyable, but at other times there is something (that I can’t quite put my finger on) that seems a bit off kilter.  It is not enough to negate my enjoyments, but it certainly makes me ponder, and perhaps that is a good thing anyway.  In the end not being able to fully grasp this beer makes it that much more intriguing.

Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson AZ

Caged and corked 750 pours a solid golden yellow and stands in the glass with a mightly glow like that of lava. Huge dense cap of firm white foam floats ever so loftily to the height of about two inches with ease. Keeps about a half inch of it always sitting. Mega impressive. Light streams are noticeable along the glass edge within the golden glow of color. Lacing is delicately patched in moderate splotches. A looker of an ale.

Aroma is medium or so in tone with a grassy edged citrus of tangerine, pineapple, and dullish lemon. Little perks of peppery spice and bubble gum esters makes for some fun notings on the nose as it warms. Caramel becomes a bit more evident as well.

Taste is firm and solid with a wonderfully thick caramel loaded malt thats completely laced with all sorts of fun citrusy spices and yeast play. Mild, dullish flavors that last and last are what makes this quite spectacular. The caramel totally backs up this floral spiced citrus thats super dulled with a slimming after thickness in a plummy orange marmalade and lemon/pineapple jam. Sugary and darkly sweet and totally yummy. Nice little mixing yeasty spice and grab with a complexing feel and thick play and the palate.

So, along with that, this has the perfect body and feel for a Triple. At least the way I favor them. Thick, smooth, and fairly beefy with malt. Great lasting flavors and finish with a slender side to its spice and citrus thats quite sugary thick and playful just like the candy it simulates. The caramel is divine in this stuff. Lovely. Warm. Tasty and lengthy. The 9% is barely evident as it warms gradually throughout each sip adding to its sippable, yummifingly yummyness.

Drinkable to the point of easy going sipping with an intriguing pull for more after each one of those sips. A Solid F*ckin Tripel !

Side note: Served at 50 degrees F. and only got better as it warmed, around 56 - 58. Perfect.

Bottle at home.
Yellow with a large white head, fine lacings. Aroma heavy malty (fruity, citrus notes). Flavor heavy sweet. Full body, strong in alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2006 **UPDATE: 10-13-06: ADD a few crystals of clear Belgian Candi sugar to the glass- the result is a very sweet treat!** Ive been a devotee of this Triple for several years now, and it never disappoints! Good marshmallow, butterscotch (not diacettyl!) bouquet, excellent head retention, (Brussels lace). Take special care to serve this between 50 - 60 degrees F. Serve in a Trappist goblet. I am one of those weirdos that would pair this with almost any food. Now- to tap into my "mixologist" side- to create a "Kicked Up" Triple, pour a 11.2 Fl Oz. bottle into a trappist goblet, and then.... add a 1/2 shot of Yukon Jack Canadian Liquor. The high alcohol does NOT dissipate the head of the beer and adds to the sweetness (and strength!) It compliments the taste wonderfully! Dont go overboard with the Yukon Jack- use it in the following proprotions: for every 11.2 Oz., use a half a shot of Yukon Jack. Now you do the math to set the proportions for the amount of this Triple  you are drinking. Its great warming drink for the Winter that is soon approaching.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2006 Poured from the bottle to a cloudy, dark orange color with thick, highly carbonated,  off-white head and good lacing. Initial aroma was slightly sour fruit. As beer warmed, the scent of the 9% alcohol became more noticeable, but at no time overpowering. Likewise, the alcohol crept in nicely in the taste to help accent the fruit and hint of spices. Finish was smooth and long. I really enjoyed this beer.

One of those top-notch tripels.  Aroma reminiscient of Karmeleit.  Very stingy flavor, also much like the Kameleit.  If Tripels are your thing, you would be proud to come back to this again and again.  And again.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 cloudy honey colored under a medium sized fizzy white head.  aroma of vanilla, marshmallow, tropical fruit, alcohol.  flavor is spicy and fruity with notes of apples,  huge bubblegum notes with pineapple, and marshmallow.  some alcohol shows up.

Bottle at Paters Vaetje, Antwerpen. Orangey golden, hazy with an eggwhite-like head. Toffee aroma as well as some grassy hoppiness, even ryebread nose. Toffee and ryebread flavours and a good balancing bitterness. Good carbonation, dry mouthfeel, full-bodied. Not as clean as a traditional tripel, but a great beer nevertheless.
Draft at the Birerria, Washington, D.C. Poured golden with a firm white head. Yeasty aroma and a spicy, yeasty flavor with lots of alcohol notes in the finish. A truly great Tripel!
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 Golden colour with a big head. Nose is sweet fruit and alcohol. Very sweet and lively beer. Quite nice

dark amber color but a bit mirky
good head-to-body ratio 
malty citrus after-taste
brewed for royalty
i will gladly try others from this brewer...if I can find them!!
light yellow, and the aroma here you will find some gras some sand, sweetness, and alcohol
Excellent belgian. Pours a mirky blonde, with a good head. Aroma is yeasty and fruity. Flavor is apricots, bready yeast, and a nice tart sweetness, very refined.

Pours slightly hazy golden with a large white soft head.  Aroma is light fruits, yeast , sugar, bit of citrus.  Flavor has some breadiness, but dominated by light fruits, some corriander, citrus in the finish.  Mouthfeel is smooth, bit overcarbonated.

Cork reads 2/05.  Pours hazy yellow / orange with a healthy white head.  Aroma is fruity and spicy with white grape, plum, pepper, vanilla, earthiness and alcohol.  Medium / full bodied with sharper than normal carbonation for the style.  Taste is fruity with light spice - think earthy fell with banana hints.  Finish has spiciness from hops, banana comes out more and there is an ABV kick.  Overall a nice tripel, but the alcohol is not hidden as well as in many others.

Bottled. Pours a slightly hazy medium orange/golden color. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Some candy-like sugary scents. A dark almost vinous quality along with yeast as well. Flavor is dark and rich. Some yeast and a hint of grain. Some fig and/or raisin. A touch of alcohol in the finish. Good tripel.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2007 Draught from The Map Room. Pours a pale hazy golden color, with a thin white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is strong on the citrus fruits, and yeast, with noticeable maltiness. Flavor is a nice yeasty fruit, with some pronounced banana flavor, and a warming finish.
Poured a hazy golden yellow color with a small white head.  Yeasty fruit easters in the aroma.  Some gum and light colored fruits.  Yeasty with light alcohol.  Lively mouthfeel.

Pours yellow golden honey w/ a huge spritzy froth leaving a small puddle of golden nectar at the top. Aroma is fresh w/ hops and sharp malt. Medium to full nectar w/ ample residual effers w/ a few streams of champagne bubbles. Flavors are rich and slightly fruity w/ banana gum, pine, honey, sharp malt. Complex and well balanced. Not too fruity. Slight alcohol on the finish w/ perfect bittering. Connoisseurs choice!
very crisp tasting golden sexily carbonated belgian banana and lemon zest and grass came in my head while sippin this syssurp
Bottle. Color is golden, with a nice big head with excellent duration. Aroma is fruit and malt. Light malt flavor, some light hints of fruit, with some fruity showing through.
Bottle. Crispy white fluffy but lasting head. Hazy yellow body. Sweet fruity aroma. Fruity yet spicy yeast flavor.
Bottle. Nice big head with excellent duration. Color is golden. Aroma is fruit and malt. Taste is sweet and fruity.

Olney Beer & Fine Wine Tasting.  Nice fluffy head with good retention, bananas and spice in the nose.  Nice carbonation on the palette; crisp with lemons and bread - though slightly more malty than one might expect from a tripel.  Still, quite enjoyable.

Highly carbonated! The cork popped wihout warning! Pours light amber with plenty of yeast hazing. Plenty of friuts in the mix along with a nice blend of hopps. Might deserve a rerate as i sampled it pretty warm....

The aroma is super sweet like hard sugar candy with yeast, malt, and spices. The appearance is a lightly amber gold with a small head. The flavor is slightly medicinal but has fruits, sugar, malt, and warming alcohol. The palate is on the lighter side but still smooth and not watery. I like most things about this beer.
From cask - Cloudy amber color with a small creamy white head. Sweet spiced Aroma with hints of lemon. Light malt flavor, some light hints of fruit, with some sharp spices showing through.

Hazy yellow coloured, with some carbonation and a large white head. Rather sweet spicy aroma, little yeasty touches and some fruity (banana, ...) hints. Nice full body. Bitter sweet spicy finish with some alcoholic touches. A very nice abbey tripel.
Bottle, thick dark yellowish beer with a light haze to it.  Very light and sweet (for a triple).  A very pleasent amount of spice.  Not nearly as yeasty as I was expecting. Lovely

Bottle.  Pours extremely hazy, golden in color with a thick white head that last.  Looks more like a weizen.  Aroma is sweet and spicey with some pepper notes.  Hint of banana.  Flavor:  Very fruity and sweet upfront.  Spices definitely there and with the hops, attempt to balance the sweetness, though falling short.  Alcohol is warming...can taste it a little in the finish....definitely detracts.  Overall, its a very nice tripel but falls a little short of being a truely great beer.  I would drink again though.
What else can be said.  This is a great Belgian triple.  A must try for any triple lover (that sounds funny  am I just being immature?)

Bottle. Nice soft banana bread, apple,  and clove nose. Hazy light gold body with a thick attractive foamy head. Soft mouthfeel with a touch of alcohol and CO2. Notes of brown sugar, alcohol, floral notes, cinnamon, watered down whisky, warming going down, cotton, and a big herbal/phenol presence I cant put my finger on. Very enjoyable, one of the better Triples that I have had.

Pours a cloudy gold with a nice, long lasting head. Aroma is sugary sweet and spicy as hell, yeasty with artichoke and beets. The flavor shares a lot with the other GC beer Ive had, the Grand Cru, in that it has a sweet sucrose taste that is very distinct and quite pleasing. It is lively and spicy in the mouth, sweet but also a touch sour at the finish, slightly harsh but very drinkable. There is a certain licorice/anise flavor that shows up as it warms, as well. If I homebrewed, Id love to cultivate this yeast and see what I could do with it.
Hazy yellow, white head. Apricot, peach nose with some hints of yeast. Fruity flavour, with belgian yeast most present. Some hints of vanilla. Slight spicy finish.

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a cloudy gold with a lasting off white head {looked more like a Hefe}. Aromas of apple, hint of banana and some spice. Palate was light bodied and warming. Flavors of carmel, light fruitiness and a hint of spice with a sweet warming finish.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2006 On tap at Brouwers. Cloudy golden with a medium head. Mild aroma of yeast and fruit. Same flavors in the taste...very nice. Very spicy...a little too much alcohol taste for me though.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Bottled 0,33L. Much creamy and bulky head, optimal persistence and adhesion. Rather clear yellow/orange color, a lot hazy. Dense and decidedly impenetrable one. Much flowery and alcoholic scent; pleasant notes of wine cellar, dried flower, leaven and mildew. Pungent, wrapping, solid and much alcoholic taste. Rather sweetish and nearly balsamic on the end. Valid but with some excess.

(B.B. 11/05) Light brown, slightly yellow colored. Big white head. Interesting aroma: orange, pineapple, mild spices, alcohol, honey and sweetness, complex aroma. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is also rich: fruits, pineapple, spices, yeast, good hoppy tones, aftertaste has toffee, strong chocolate and medium alcohol.

Poured a light yellow gold with a big frothy white head.  Aroma is sweet, yeasty, and a hint of citrus.  Falvor is orages, bannana, with a hint of clove and just enough hop balance to give it a clean finish.  Body is a bit thin.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus for beer night at my house. Ive had better abbey triples, this was good though by all means, i expected it to taste a little better, was not impressed.

(04.02.06) 330 mL brown bottle from Morels Restaurant and Café, Beijing, China. 9% ABV. ottled 4/04 and labeled as best consumed by 4/22/06.  Poured clear amber with long-lasting large white head. Good lacing. Soft carbonation. Sweet malt and caramel in the nose. Medium bodied Belgium ale that starts dry with slight malt sweetness and pronounced tangy sour fruity flavor. Finished dry with malt aftertaste. Good drinkable strong Belgium ale with a pronounced sour note. Not for the meek.

Not quite there as an outstanding Abbey Tripel.  Flavor strives to get there and starts subtle yet never achieves the complexity of the style.  A straw pale w/ orange tints.  Some banana aroma that fades, good lacing and a finely built head.  Satisfying though not great.

Light delicate aroma, notes of banana, pineapple, flowers (maybe roses or violets), a touch of lemon citrus, and bread dough. A light hazy yellow that almost wants to glow orange, and a huge tight creamy head that is going nowhere. A light coriander spice nose shows up as some of the fruitiness subsides. Big sweet up front, strangely clean, with a tartness that feels like alot of alcohol whopping the sides of your tongue. Fair amount of hops in the finish, but they are quickly overwhelmed by a lingering fuselly alcohol finish. Let this warm for the fruit esters to really come through, particularly banana. Feels a little slick, lacking the airy fluffiness in the better tripels.

Bottle.
Cloudy yellow coloured with a medium sized  white head.
Sweet aroma of fruits, caramel and "carolus-yeast".
Sweet flavour of caramel, fruits and, spices and "carolus-yeast".

750 mL bottle.  Pours golden straw yellow with a patchy white head, small and dissipates to a film, frothy and sticky lacing.  Aroma is floral and fruity, citrus hops. light malt (hay, straw) and yeast (dough, grass) with an alcohol nose.  Medium sweet yeast (dough) and fruity acidic hop flavor, flowers and earth notes, sugary and a malt body, lasting flavor.  Light bodied, lively carbonation and fizzy palate.

Bottled.  A blonde coloured beer with a nice large white head and good lacing.  The aroma is spicy, peppery and yeasty together with some yeasty fruit.  The spicy hops and yeastiness continue into the taste together with a little lemon citricity.  Its  alittle too thin for my liking but still quite decent.

22 cl bottle.  Cloudy yellow gold body with a small fluffy head that dissipated quickly.  Very nice aroma of pineapple, orange and grapefruit.  Pleasant light fruity flavor with orange, pineapple, some honeydew melon, just the right touch of sweetness.  The alcohol presence is also quite apparent.  Rich body and silky mouthfeel with mild carbonatoin.  A nice beer.

Pours golden with a wispy off-white head. Sparkling body. Aroma of sweet yeasty esters, notes of honey, apple, white wine, orange peel, and coriander. A bit too sweet with unusual esters on the nose. Taste is sweet and sticky, with esters, phenols, and high alcohols leading the way. Notes of cloves, spicy alcohol, bubble gum, ending with a long phenolic note. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly sticky with aggressive, lively carbonation. I knew I wasnt going to love this beer as soon as I smelled it. Granted, its not bad by any means, but in my opinion, tripels are one of the hardest styles to flawlessly execute. Not bad, but not great.

Bottle, 33cl. Hazy yellow almost orange colour with a medium and disappointing white head, rapidly diminishing. Aroma is sweet and fuity with a few spicy notes. Very smooth and effervescent. Flavour is slightly yeasty and malty with a pronounced sweetness. In fact, sometimes the sweetness is a little too much. Nevertheless, a very good Triple.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 (Bottle) Deep, cloudy golden color. Big, frothy white head that disappears rather quickly. Aroma is potent mix of sweet, spice, orange, yeast and floral notes. Fizzy on the tongue. Taste is sweet and malty with a mix of spices, bubblegum aftertaste. Lively carbonation.
On tap at the Brickskeller in Washington DC.  Nose of apple, slight corriander spice. Taste is slight hop, apples, citrus.  Fizzy thin palate.  Trailing taste is slightly alcoholic and citrusy.

Hazy golden color, thin head, very sweet,... a bit overwalming, some nice spices, dont taste the big alcohol level, I wonder of they use only natural ingredients,..so brewery sent the ingredients and I will re-rate

Sweet upon full warming, yet still fairly clean. A bit of herbality cuts through the sugars. Some mushroomy woodiness, a little like what I get from aged Allagash Triple. Fair body and holds together well, if too sweet...The aroma is nicely spicy with pepper and pineish components. I havent seen this in 12 oz. lately - is this a new batch?
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle. Pours a hazzy blonde with a frothy head.  The flavor is of citrus fruits, pear, apple, grapes. The aroma is  full of sweet fruits, very tangy.  A very refined Triple.

Hazy orange with a thin white head.  Not much retention when served warm.  Hints of white wine, orange, candy apple, apricot. banana, grapes, lemons and cloves come into the aroma.  Quite fruity.  Taste was quite floral with the apple,banana and white wine dominating.  Palate was very sugary and had a thick body.  This a strong Tripel yet is was very easy to approach.  Well done.

Pours somewhat of a cloudy golden orange with a medium white head which dissipates as it warms. Pear, white wine/white grapes in the nose; very fruity. Flavor has notes of sweet pale malt, apple, pear, spices, lemon, white wine, caramel and a little raisin. Pleasantly sweet, the hops establish enough of their presence to balance it out but most of the flavor comes from the malt and yeast. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and spritzy yet soft carbonation. Overall, quite enjoyable.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Thick and cloudy orange color with a white head. Aroma has lots of spices, malts, yeast and some citrus I believe. Flavor begins very sweet and malty with a nice and smooth flow all throughout the beer. Finish is very smooth and warming and it hides the alcohol until it gets pretty warm. Then you can taste the full 9%. I definitely knocked back a couple of these babies. Very tasty.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2006 A strong tripel in alcohol and taste. a bit more brown than the average tripel. great white head and complexity in aroma and taste. Like a good Belgium beer it has a great long lasting finish.

33cl bottle.  Pours cloudy gold with an ample white head that lasts forever and laces right to the bottom of the glass.  Spicy banana aroma with a little citrus thrown in for fun.  The flavor is so sweet, you expect it to become annoying, but it doesnt.  It simply masks the alcohol.

Golden hazy beer with a phenomenal head. Nice and fluffy. Aroma was pretty complex with notes of spiciness, grassy hops, lemon grass, pineapple and bananna. I felt this was more akin to a saison due to how fruity and light it was, than to a triple. No noticeable alcohol made this one go down very nicely.

A Mes rate:
33cl bottle from Utobeer. A very fine tripel indeed and for my money one of the best. Malty and sweet aroma. Dark hazy golden body with a well formed head and attractive lacing. Lots of sweetness in the flavour but never too much. Slight aniseed notes with a touch of toffee and caramel and also something decidedly fruity. Maybe raspberry. Alcohol shows through in the spicy finish. A very fine brew overall.

Hazilla gold pour with a dumpling of a head here. Lots of yummy yeast, fruits, and a bouqet or fresh flowers hits you in the face and taste. Some citrics and a salty aftertaste.  Some post alchohol and a faint tip of hops. enjoyable loverly.

Im not a fan of strong belguims but this is pretty good.  hazy golden color - pleasant aroma and 9% - YEAH!!
 good brew.
Hazy yellow with a medium white head.  Yeasty, fruity aroma.  Complex fruity flavor that is reminiscent of the other, darker Gouden Carolus ales.  Some saltiness in the finish.  Very good.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, tupalev, Dave B. and R. -- courtesy of me. Pours a very hazy bubbly yellow with an average size fizzy white head. Nice Lacing. Aroma of wheat, yeast, lemon, spices and sugar. Flavour follows the aroma but with some added hops and lingering alcohol, its nice and complex. Light bodied with a lively mouthfeel. I like the other Gouden Carolus beers Ive had more but this is still a damn fine beer.

Slightly cloudy golden pour with an energetic and rising head. Overall and pleasing aroma of malt, spice and yeast- well blended. Full in the mouth, but not sweet to start, with spice and subtle hoppy bitters in the finish with a nice conclusion.

Bottle shared with the crew, thanks blankboy.  Yellow pour, medium white head.  Yeast, lemon, bread aroma.  medium mouthfeel. Lemon and yeast taste, slightly sweet as well.  Ends with a maple syrup like sweetness.  Very easy to drink and well made, it just didnt blow my socks off like others from this brewery.  Nice stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, tupalev, Dave B. & R. - courtesy of blankboy. Pale gold with a medium white head. Aroma is a slightly funky and herbal, with notes of band-aid and lemon. Body is soft. Flavour is a bit tart, with notes of wheat, yeast, spice and fruit. Very nice stuff.

BottlePerfumed, somewhat cloying,  sweet fruit aroma. Cloudy yellow hue, tanned blanket head. Fruity (apples, peaches, tropical) and flowery base flavor, earthy potatolike aftertaste.
Light mouthfeel, slightly sparkly.

Cloudy amber with a big lasting creamy white head. The aroma is sweet and citrussy/toffee-ish, the flavour is sweet citrus and alcholic with a touch of spice but i like it. Kind of different to the other Tripels ive had but will deff try again.

Bottle (330ml).  Poured murky deep orange with an average white creamy head.  Aroma of yeast, sweet roast caramel malt, spices - a fruity, malty treat.  Taste follows directly on, with alcohol and a little musty woodiness in the mix - sryupy, sharp and warming, moderately lively.  Very nice, I like all the Gouden Carolus offerings Ive tried immensely.

Aroma of honey, spice, alcohol, yeast, and fruit.  Flavor is sweet, fruity with a medium body and soft palate.  A bit of alcohol in there as well.  Very well balanced and very tasty.  No characteristic is too dominant, but the most dominant is fruit.  Light chewy malt.  Complex.

Pour is par for a tripel, with an aroma of wildflowers and a little alcohol.  Reasonably lively on the palate with above average acidiity.  A little vinous and sharp, but warm and toasty almost gives it proper balance.  Finish is crisp.  Less sweet and more wild than most of this type.

Pours cloudy, straw yellow with a large, frothy head. Very earthy, woody nose. Spritzy on the tongue, with a generous bite of hops. Aftertaste is dry with just a hint of the alcohol, and lingering esters. Different, but good.

Poured from the bottle this beer appears a light gold with a bubbly good head. Aroma is spicy with grassy hops and has a lemon grass, banana fruit accent. Peppery flavor with a larger bitter hop presence than a traditional Tripel. The bottle mentions "imperial ale"which is quite fitting. Has a "mellow balance" in the finish with a touch of sweet banana left on the tougue. Mostly dry but lively and fizzy moutfeel. An unusual but quite good Tripel.

pours a really light golden yellow color with a large, foamy lasting head and lots of sticking lacing.  Aroma is grassy and hoppy and smells very Belgian.  Flavor reminds me a little of dish soap and pepper.  Slightly warming and bubbly on the palate.

This golden ale poured with a long-lasting fluffy white head. The flavor is more like a saison than like a classic Belgian Tripel - very fruity and light, with no noticeable alcohol taste and a dry finish.

2004 vintage (1.5 years in cellar).  The aroma was very saison-like, surprisingly.  Lots of hay/straw, with hints of perfume/  There was also a slight yeast and dough smell.  The head was creamy, off-white, that mostly diminished.  Body was a little hazy, amber, orange.  Initial flavor moderately sweet with a tiiny bit of acidic flavor.   Finish was lightly sweet/acidic, with a long finish.  Seemed lighter than most Tripels, while the texture was dry an dlively.  Not much of a finish.  I was really surprised at the very saison like aroma, but since I love saisons, I didnt really mind.  Since I had one of these fresh, it seems that it has picked up a more earthy slant.
Bottle. Almost clear golden colour. Peppery flavour, a little fruity.
Bottled. Pale orange hazy colour, mediumsized creamy head. Fruitish, spicy and wheaty aroma. Flavour of caramel, spices, fruits and wheat. Sweet fruitish aftertaste.

Hazy gold colour with a massive, frothy head. Sweet, spicy evocative aroma. Taste of pear and melon, fresh and delightful, with a background citric orange sourness and a slight bitter finish. Outstanding.

Beverage Warehouse, Roswell, Ga - 750 ml corked bottle. Dark golden, slightly murky with a wispy thin, lacy head, looks like champagne. Clean, fresh aroma with hints of lemon, 
butterscotch and mown grass. interesting and slightly complex flavor. Pick up some fruitiness, akin to the flavor of pears. Some estery notes, a bit of butter and some white wine. Just the right amount of spritziness, does not feel like I am drinking champagne, my complaint about some tripels. Overall, very good.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a moderate white head.  Aroma of butterscotch, musitness, and light citrus.  Flavor of spicy yeast, citrus, and malt.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Cloudy golden orange with rocky off white head. Good aroma of orangey hop, spice, honey, vanilla. Creamy mouthfel with lingering hop finish, alcohol warmth. Very good indeed.

Aroma: candy, small bit of bailing wire and a touch of apricot. Appearance: poures golden/amber with a big lasting head just off white and great lacing. With the yeast it is just hazy. Flavour: sweet apricot, floral notes and metallic hops. Palate: medium full mouthfeel finishes spiritious and leaves a metalic hop aftertaste.

Pours hazy orangish-amber with a large rocky head that sticks around for a while. When it finally recedes it leaves a frothy mesa in the middle of the glass and near-solid lacing on the sides. Very spicy and citrusy aromaoranges, fresh bread, and coriander dominate. And I swear theres some brine in there somewhere. Flavor of bread and phenols. Mediciney, acidic, and lip-puckering. Theres a slight hop finish, but thats somehow pre-overpowered by the first flavors. It had a wonderful appearance and aroma, but the flavor fell quite a bit short of my thusly formed expectations.
Cloudy amber colour, with a thin head. Aroma of citrus, flowers, raisins, yeast and esters. The flavour has acidic notes, and has a fine balance between bitterness and sweetness. Strong hoppy finish.

Pours with a golden orange body topped by a thin head with some lacing.  Its slightly sweet with a touch of candy sugar, a touch of skunkiness, a little hops and a touch of alcohol esters in the nose.  Medium bodied, dry and smooth.

Sweet floral aroma. Milky amber color with a beautiful fluffy white head. Candy sugar sweetness int he fore followed by some floral flavors and malt. Finishes very suddenly and leaves a lip smacking fruity malt aftertase.

6 June 2005 -(Enich Anders B&B) - Complex sweet malt and complex hoppiness, with vinuos (celery) aromas.  Cloudy light brown colour, great head and lacing.  Spiritous malt, some nutty and big hop complex flavours.  Big tangy aftertaste with some lingering back of the throat aftertatse, but perhaps a bit too much.

Not as fruity, sweet, or complex as some others of the style, but still a very good beer.  Substantial body. There is a thick white head that lasts so long I was getting impatient to drink the cloudy, dark orange beer.  Powerful aroma of sweet fruit.  Flavor is primarily sweet with a bit of the alcohol coming through. Sweet malt in the finish.  This cant stand up to Tripel Karmeliet but is vastly superior to Westmalle and many others.

Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a big white head. Fruity, floral and yeasty aroma. Taste is sweet, fruity, malty, spicey with a light and long bitter finish. Fairly high carbonation, with a foamy-ish mouthfeel. This is very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Bottle. Light amber color with a big white head. Lots of yeast in aroma along with apple, banana, spice, and sweet malt. Sweet malt/candy sugar flavor with spice and lemon. High carbonation. Alcohol present.

THE BIG 500!!!sampled from 330ml bottle.pours a murky golden body with a HUGE white head.the head leaves layers of thick white web on the side of the trappist glass.after 5 minutes or so f letting the head sit,i took my first whiff.aroma was very crisp and contained apples,grapes,flowers,and a tiny bit of belgian yeast.the flavor was also full of apples,grapes,summer flowers,and some begian yeast.this is light,airy,but still full of flavor.

Bottle.  Murky yellow in colour, tall lasting white head, nice lace.  The aroma was soapy, floral, with lots of candy sweetness and yeast.  The flavour was very floral, lots of yeast, noticeable alcohol, apples and peaches.  Dry mouthfeel, medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes with a medium lingering bitterness.  A young sample, perhaps this needs more time.

33 cl Botlle. Yeast in bottom. Golden colour with a fast disappearing head. Very delicate aroma, of some gym or candy. Big mouthful of malt, sweetness, spices and end up winery, what a great taste, a very good tripel.

(Bottle 33 cl) Fully golden, slightly hazy with a tall and frothy head. Yeast sediment. Very potent brew with a prominent, warming alcohol glow. Yeasty, spicy and very malty with a pronounced sweetness. Nice and wellmade Tripel. 050802

One of my favourite breweries and one of my favourite styles, so there may be  a little bias in this rating. Happened to be a wonderful brew that seems to stand alone from this brewers big dark ales. Tasted from the bottle and poured into its own gold rimmed chalice, cool and not cold. A big dense and creamy white head formed atop a hazy orange-gold body. Head lasted the distance and left a web of lace down the glass. Intense, treacly sweet candi sugar nose with a strong balance of pears, apples and zesty oranges. Only a light amount of yeast and alcohol spice, peppery, was detectable and this came through long into drinking. In the mouth a blend of zesty fruity esters, prickly, medicinal and mellowing alcohol and yeast spice, and sweet candi and vanilla were amplified by the high carbonation that moved things along quickly. Light fresh herb flavours and leafy hops come in in the back and dry out with the alcohol to follow through to a long warming and reasonably smooth swallow. Light in body and filling in the stomach, this was a lovely beer, perfect for the winter,  that came highly recommended by the boys at the Intl beer shop, W. Leederville, and for that I thank them. Lovely!!! (33cL, BBE 01/07)

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2010  Update 9/5/10 This a very good Tripel, Huge retaining head is attractive, very balanced and not as sweet as most others, really nice.750ml Corked Slightly hazed golden with a thick head. Spicy aroma, peppery, citrus, fruity and lightly vinous notes. Medium body with a soft mouthfeel and crisply effervescent. Spicy fruity flavors. Nice by the book Tripel.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Spiritus hop malt aroma. Murky yellow colour with very thick sudsy head and fantastic lacing. Strong sharp flavour with malt flowers and hops. Smooth palate.

pour is a light blond with a bit of pure white head.  Aroma is at first a little disapointing, but after a few wiffs I thought that it actually wasnt bad and in keeping with the style.  There are hints of orange and other fruits in addition to the nice maltyness.  Flavor is very good.    Its light and airy with a citrus component.  Good beer, Id drink it again.
Pours a fairly thick orangish brown body with a small but nice head. The aroma is fruity with hints of raisins. Sweet lingering finish, but not as good as their other brews that Ive had.

330ml bottle yields a cloudy, orange-amber colored ale with a large tan head and excellent lacing. Aroma is caramel, honey, orange and hint of alcohol. The initial palate is honey sweet, giving way to fruity esters of overripe banana, citrus and raisin.  Effervescent and medium bodied and quite smooth, this ale has a long-lasting, moderately hopped finish with pleasing alcohol warmth and dryness.
somewhat overpowering for a long lunch, it needed much food. Floral hops and honey yeast and orange aroma.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2005 2005 bottle at the Mondial Ratebeer Tasting, 6/4/05.  Honey-orange-amber.  White head recedes quickly to ring.  Lightly hazy, bottle conditioned, with small bubbles rising.  Aroma is doughy white bread, starfruit, citrus (tangerines, oranges), peppery spices, and perfumey hops and alcohol phenols.  Thick yeast presence as well.  Flavor is perfumey as well, quite phenolic and has a rich, malty doughiness.  Pepper and alcohol on the end, with a firm carbonation.  Sweet candied peaches and orange rinds.  Fluffy, malty mouthfeel.  Perfume lingers with spicy hops.  Quite the adventure.  Very good young, should age well.

Couleur ambrée tirant vers lorangée, grosse mousse plutôt persistante.  Présence levurée et plutôt sucré en arômes, sucre brun, cassonade, sucre à la crème.  Gros malt épais et collant en bouche véhicule de toutes sortes de flaveurs sucrées restant toujours bien balancées.  Texture crémeuse, effervescence piquante et bien présente.  Finale un brin amérisante et métallique cachant bien lalcool.  Un exemple bien réussi du style.
Ive had better abbey triples, this was good though by all means, i expected it to taste a little better, but it was still good, id buy it again.

in the bottle. This pours about as dark golden as possible. The white head had little staying power. The aroma is like a caramel toffee latte. You can smell the sweetness. Flavor is a substantial malty caramel taste which is remarkably smooth and drinkable for a 9% beer. Not filled with the complexities of many triples. The yeast cake in the bottom of my bottle was like a hockey puck.

Appealing aroma of fruits, spices and yeast. Hazy orange pour with  a thin white head. Very good flavor of thick malt with fruits, spices and yeast, the finish is sweet. The body is medium with a creamy, slightly powdery texture and soft carbonation. Excellent, true to the Gouden Carolus standard.

bière blonde avec à réflection orange. lOdeur de cette bière est franche avec des impressions de banane mûre et goût de marmelade. Goût plein et rond. cette bière est très buvable et elle a un goût original.

bottle. golden-amber body, small white head. alcoholic caramel aroma with lots of sugar. lively carbonation. sweet caramel flavour with some cookies in the finish. I wasnt expecting this beer to taste like this but it turned out to be tasty and flavourful.

Deep golden. Big white head quickly recedes to ring. Massive honeyed sweet maltiness. Cough drops paired among floral yeast. Thick litchi maltiness, honeyed alcohol. Smoky and alcoholic as it warms like any Het Anker. Drying out nicely in mouth, but theres too much malt to manage any kind of balance. A bit too sweet and fatiguing ultimately, but this is great smelling material. Sugar caney full bodied palate, moderately high carbonation, a bit too thick to be tongue cleaning. Thanks Clark!
Ratebeer Mondial Gathering (tiggmtl). Épices, agrumes, miel, raisins, alcool. Levure présente. Belle rondeur du malt. Houblon bien présent.

From a 33cl bottle.

pours a hazy gold with a 1/4 inch snow white head. Persistent head and persistent lacing. Smell is fruity and yeasty. Hints of sweetness and spice.

Taste is much like the smell, spicy and sweet. Light hint of cinnamon apples. Sour and peppery as it finishes. Really smooth and oddly creamy (for a tripel) Really one of the nicest textures Ive had in a tripel. This one does not reveal its strength in the body, though very flavorful. Watch out, itll sneak up on you.

Man,I liked the spicey nose from this.Has some sweet fruitiness to it but I guess that the yeast in this gives it a apricot/aromatic aroma.This is a little flatter in flavor as the spiciness is more subdued that I would have liked.Still a fine tripel.

#200! On draught @ Kulminator. Hazy golden coloured beer with a nice foamy white head. Malty aroma, taste is fairly sweet with fruity notes (pear) and some spices. Very smooth, full  mouthfeel. Wonderful beer
750 ml bottle, pours cloudy golden. with a thick rocky head. aroma is spice and malt. taste is malt. fruit, apricot, clove,and spice. a pretty good beer.

Golden body with a touch of amber in it. Good size white head that left loads of lacing. Aroma of mandarins, spice and alcohol. Taste was soft and smooth, medium body, sweet but not overly so, and a light sweet alcoholic finish. This beer was easy to drink but at 9% you couldnt quite have big session of them. A good pale ale ramped right up to the max?

750 ml corked and caged bottle pours a cloudy yellow orange with a nice off white head that leaves a sticky lacing in my glass. Fruity yeasty aroma of pears and apples. Sweet and malty fruity pear and tart apple flavors with a slight bubblegum yeasty taste. Medium-full body with a carbonated crisp mouthfeel, alcohol presence come out as it warms, finishes sweet, very nice.
Keg @ Akkurat, StockholmBlonde, slightly woodsy. Fruits, mostly apples, present. Yeast and alcohol appearant.

bottle from brickskeller.  wonderful.  a sweet triple with malty, wheaty notes that finishes how i expect a triple to: slightly on the sweet side.  color is light cold, a subdued yeastiness gives the beer extra body and character.

White full lasting head. Amber color. Aroma is moderately sweet, fruity with apricots and light alcohol notes. Flavor is malty, sweet with fruity (ripe pear and peach) tones and a light spicy accent, ending in a moderately sweet finish. Medium bodied.
A very nice Tripel. Appearance is a little weak.  Spicy, full,  and smooth flavor. Hoppiness is light.
UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 Very nice triple with light yellowish head, a citrucy aroma and a full, fruity flavor. Light spiciness. It has a slightly bitter finish and hides the alcohol quite well.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2006 It was ok, too, but the flavor was too similiar to the "Keizer" one. BUt anyway, it did not stop to flow unitl it was half empty or so. THe flavo was ok.

Pours a lightly hazy bronze with a frothy and thinly-lacing white head.  Aroma has a touch of vanilla and licorice with some bready Belgian yeast and a hint of light fruit.  Starts with nice caramel malty sweetness, some yeasty esters, and a touch of peppery spice toward a dry bready finish.  Hides the alcohol quite well.  A nice tripel.
Think Karmeliet with a little more spice and a little less sweetness.  Not bad.  Lots of floaties, though.

A vey sweet triple not cloying but right at my limit for the style. beautiful initial head with poor retention nice cnady sugar upfront Turbinado? with a apricots and white grapes to finish out the palate.

Large head on this cloudy golden body. Excellent taste for a blonde. Taste has sweet notes, honey or other, citrus fruits and spices. Alcohol is well hidden and the general impression is excellent. A pleasure to drink. Finish is bitter.

Cloudy gold with a tall frizzy head, this ale has has a yeasty-fruit aroma laden with spices and a trace of alcohol.  Light-bodied, its got honey, apples, oranges, and spices in the taste.  Theres a dry, slightly bitter finish.  A nice triple... nothing great.

Pours a two-finger white head that vanishes without a trace lace.  Cloudy amber color.  Light-medium carbonation and light-medium bodied.  Nose is distinctly raisins, starts sweet and finishes sweet and sour but mellow.  No hint of alcohol!!  Another excellent triple.  330ml bottle for $3.49 from Hoosick St. Discount Bev, Troy, NY.

Cloudy and tan with a touch of orange. Minimal head and medium high carbonation. The aroma is spicy and ladden with alcohol, sweet yeast and roasted honey. Golden flavors touched by the sun. Apple, summer, morning dew and the consciousness of youth. Palate is rich and satisfying. Overall, very good, quite complex and certainly flavorful. Not really an attractive looking beer.
Hazy gold with a big merangue head. Mellon aroma. Fizzy, sweet, slightly yeasty and a hint of chalk. Alcohol is well hidden. Delicate and nice but not my favorite.
Bottle. Hazy golden color with a big white head. Sweet fruity spicy aroma and  sweet malty fruity taste. Medium to full body and a sweet light alcoholic finish.
Yellow colour with big white head. Lots of fruit in the aroma. sweet and malty flavor with some alcohol in the finish.
One of the best Tripels Ive had.  Nicely malty, but still on the dry side for style.  Fairly long lasting head and lovely effervescense.  Reminds me a bit of Karmiliet, maybe a bit maltier.

33 cl bottle; Dark yellow with white puffy head. Just the perfect amount of yeast sediment pours on top of the foam. Great! Nose is mostly alcohol with some faint sweetness. Flavour is very smooth with perfect of bitterness to balance, some acidouness from the yeast. High but smooth carbonation. A very nice triple.

Pours a cloudy light orange with a thick and creamy head.  No lacing, but the head does stick around for quite some time.  Aroma is slightly sweet with some coriander and oragne.  Taste is a nice blend of fruit and spiciness.  Some banana and bready notes come through as well some cinnanmon and orange peel.  Overall, its really pretty good.  Maybe just a hint of alcohol on the back end, but far from distracting.  A good tripel.

Bottle.  A slightly hazy amber color with a rich foamy white head.  The aroma has a nice candy and spice, and the flavor includes banana, orange and a little pepper.  Quite a nice triple.  Enjoyed with family and friends on Christmas Eve.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2004 Very Bananaey aroma.  Baby food banana.  it has a Very smooth mouthfeel.  This beer changes many times, citrus comes out, caramel as it warms,. black tea like flavor too.Liked it alot..

Hazy bronze with a huge foamy white head. Some spotty lacing. As said before by the heemster, a nose of caramel and pears. Alcohol as well. That was not hidden too well. Spicy, citrusy hops. The caramel comes out more, the alcohol is better hidden, and the pears arent really there. I do detect a touch, but not too much. Bitter hops roll into the equation here as well as hitting at the end with some pepperyness/spiciness. On the second drink, I do notice the alcohol, but nowhere is it as prevelant as in the nose. The body is nice and creamy with a spicy, tangy palate. Ends with fruit and spices... and hints of alcohol.

The body is a reddish copper with a huge white head. Nice rich aroma of caramel and pears. Taste has golden delicious apples. Also a full, creamy mouthfeel. the taste has caramel and a nice cinnamon spice finish. Alcohol is present, but not distracting. A nice tripel, but nothing to get excited about.

Dull gold color that starts with a towering head that melts down to a small lacing.  Aroma of spices and corriander.  Good lord what is that taste?!  My bet is on tobacco.  Slightly sweet taste, but that spice/tobacco overpowers everything.  Tasty, but a little much.

Marmalade Coloring With White Head.   Malty..with a Harsh Spice...Almost Peppery in the Very Beginning...  Alcohol Barely Noticeable....Some Citurs..and Lighter Spice...Overall, One of the Smoothest and Easiest To Drink Tripels Ive Ever Had...
A bit cloyingly sweet at first but dries out a little as the glass empties.  Malty, with big coriander and orange peel flavours.  Alcohol shows itself but doesnt overpower.  Nice.

Cloudy orange color with a big white head that quickly dissipated. Spicy, yeasty aroma with a lot of banana in there. Spicy flavor of baked bread, citrus
and banana. As it warmed, the flavor of caramel started coming through. An
aftertaste of black tea that was very pleasant. Very unique and delicious.

Pours light orange with a tall foaming off white head. Fantastic spiced bread, herbal aroma. Caramel, kiwi, pepper. Toasty. Very dry with some sharp honey notes. Grass and strawberry in the finish. Although not a text book tripel, this stuff is very tastey.
Golden copper body with a faint aroma. Initial fruity bitterness followed by a light malt palate finishing with light crispness.

This was a very good brew, I was extremely impressed by the how well the beer went down.  Smooth and silky, but still packed that venemous bite that made it special.  It had a blend of dark, chocolately, and nutty flavors ... solid.

One of the most unique tripels Ive yet had - burnt copper color, with spicy, musty, earthy aroma - interesting mix of flavors, with peaches, pickled ginger, nutmeg, and a touch of cinnamon - long, mellow, finish that tastes somewhat like christmas cookies - very different for a tripel, but very good.

I have had the triple from Het Anker, which I personally consider to be a world class brewery many times before, but this is the first review.

Golden.

A simply intoxicating aroma, lovely at times, not as others. Notes of cinnamon, deep malt, peaches, pears, icing and orange peels. 

Its better fresh but this is still great. Tropical fruitiness (lemon, pear, pineapple) throughout along with a mild hop bite on the finish. Just a great triple.

Hazy copper with a beige head.  Aroma is fruit and spice and malty.  Sweet.  Gently carbonated.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied.  The alcohol is evident but not overpowering.  The taste is somewhat sweet and biting.

Holy Guacamole! This corked little devil came out with NO effort--BOOM!
And now my trousers are wet...

Muddy golden hue...vast mass of fluffy foam, white as snow sits on top and elegantly collapses, leaving gentle lace...Aroma: yeast, citric, but light, airy, a little honeyish...Taste: mmm, just right!

Elaborate? I shall. A garden of fruit is here, apricots, peaches, oranges, banana, mix it with cream, soften it with sugar, throw some honey in it, whipped cream on top now, gently sprinkle with spices...tastiness abounds! Lightly, judiciously hopped, ample malt, incessant flavor. Body is about medium, finish is nigh-unto-eternal, light, sugary, and just about damned delicious, balance is near perfect too, nothing is overly forward, everything meets just-so, and its drinkability gets a boost from that. 
My first try with this one, and now its a new favorite, that Ill return to again and again...deeelicious!

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 Formidible in the glass, and a hazy gold, fiery orange beauty.  Tough to keep the head under control!  Esters on the nose, banana, yeast, straw.  An alcoholic bite, with diminishing flavors, that kind of leave a buzz on your tongue.  I dont mind it, but wish there was more hop and yest in the beers follow-through.
A very good beer, a malty taste with also some fruit and sugar. But the alcohol presence is a bit too strong in taste and aroma.

Bottle picked up in Belgium. Pours gold, white head. Spicy/peppery aroma. Interestingly its like a high gravity witbier, it shares similar spiceyness, and is without the dry hoppinness you find in some triples

09.12.04  330ml bottle, 2005 dated.  Dark, clouded gold; full of chunks of love.  Fine sheet of foam that persists.  Aromas of blackberry pie, biscuit, custard, orange, and honey.  Theres a bit of medicinal or artificial tang to the aroma.  Flavors seem to mimic the nose.  Nice alcohol presence integrates, especially in finish.  Cherry and berry prevalent in flavor, plum.  Citrus not so much tasted, despite being flavor forward.  Slight finishing acidity, sweet/tart overall.

Bottled (BB 12/2005)
Hazy orange with big off-white head. Aroma is fruity: prunes and grapefruit. Flavor has raisins, malt, prune. Full-bodied. Hides ABV very well, drier than Classic.

750 ml. big ole brown Belgian bottle. Corked and caged. No freshness date seen, either on bottle or cork. Greasy feeling composite cork. Loud pop forcefully ejected the cork into my hand.
Good thing I was ready for it. It has a very high level of carbonation, almost like a dry champagne. It poured out a deep golden yellow color, with a humongous white head. The head was loose and frothy, not tight like some triples. Aromas are of sweet Timothy hay, slight caramel cream aromas, and some yeasty bread. No hops aromas, but it has a very slight hops bite in the middle of the flavors. Flavors are of light caramels, some slight candi sugars, sweet pilsener malts, and of course, the yeast. Gentle vanilla flavors as well. Not much in the way of phenols, cloves or bubblegum. Gentle fruitiness to it, not overpowering at all. Finishes rather in the middle, neither sweet nor dry. Medium mouthfeel, coats the tongue for a brief second, then disappears. No alcohol aromas or flavors. A really decent triple, one of the best Ive had.
If it were a little less expensive, this would make for a very good everyday beer.

Great big frothy head.  Lasts for a while.  Slightly creamy on top.  Good carbonation.  Nice soft aroma with peaches, bit of spice (corriander), yeast  .  Color is a nice golden orange.  Slightly sweet and malty.  Good bit of spice and alcohol warming.  Soft mouthfeel.  Finish is clean, slighly bitter and has a nice alcohol warming.  SLight spice in there also.  A very good triple.

Had this beer on tap at the brewery in Mechelen in May but now having a 33cL bottle bought in Denver during the GABF last year.  It tasted better in Belgium.  This one is light golden and the aroma has an alcohol presence with maltiness.  The flavor is fairly hoppy with strong alcohol and sweetness with some spiciness.  There was some unpleasant, medicinal flavor in this bottle that I dont remember tasting in Mechelen.  I will still buy this beer if I see it in the States but it has tasted better.

33cl. Bottle.  Cloudy yellow/orange with some head and a little lacing. Slighty astringent  spiciness that turns very sweet at the end.  I think this bottle is a little off.  I have had much better Coulden Carolus beers in the past.  I wll just have to try this again.

Pours yellow/gold, with a fairly large, white head. Malt, yeast and earth aromas, similar to Duvel. Flavor is malt, yeast, and some honey. It just seems to be missing something that would put it into the upper ranks. Alcohol is very well hidden. If I hadnt known it was 9%, I would have guessed something like 6% or 7%.
Thanks to Matta for the bottle. Good triple. I actually found this to be a little to malty for me. I like mine a little sweeter. Very drinkable however and the alcohol is hidden pretty good.
Mild honey pear buttery aroma. Hazy dark golden appearance. Sweet  flavors of bananas tropical fruit walnuts and orange zest with a mild hop finish. Too sweet to rate highly.
Pours cloudy burnt golden color with with thick tan head.  Sweet, malty, orange citrusy nose.  Very fruity, yet hint of malt character.  Light alcohol presence.  Very nice finish.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 wow! what a aroma, fresh peaches, citrus, hops, just perfect for the style. Perfect appearance, very thick head, pure golden colour! Taste is explosive, this is Golden Monkey on steroids after a night out! Very easy, but oh so good, perfect mixture of sweetness, yeast, malt and hops. WHERE THE HELL ARE THE 9% ABV ???? In my eyes, this is the definition of a triple, I´m very surprised that the top raters havent rated this higher, this beats Victory, Allagash, and Westmalle by a long shot. A gold of a beer!
Thick firm head, golden orange body, slightly cloudy. Peach(baked), citrus, and sweet malt nose. Creamy, sweet mid-palate, drying finish with lingering sweet flavors of baked peachadn toasted bread.

Bottle: Poured a golden hazy beer with a huge head with perfect retention. Aroma is quite complex with a mix of yeast, hops, malts and something sweet like some orange. Taste is just incredible with a perfect mix between sweetness (this beer gotta have some candi sugar in it) and the hops. Alcohol is not noticeable at all, which is great when you have a 9% ABV beer. Overall, this is just wonderful, probably one the best discovery from my recent trip to Belgium.

Hazy blond to golden body, with a lovely thick and creamy off-white head. Aroma is very complex, spices, banana, yeast, very peppery, some orange too, apple, lovely aroma. At the first taste, you cant really understand that its a triple, cause your mind tells you that this should be a dark belgian ale. But then the spices and the fresh yeastyness hits you, and then youre sold. A good alcohol burn in the end finishes the whole deal off perfectly. A very nice and balanced brew. Im really beginning to like triples and this one is magnificent. Another fantastic brew from Het Anker.

330 ml bottle.  Thick, deep golden hazy color, smallishoff-white head.  Big choco-caramel-banana aroma with loads of spiciness (cinnamon, white peppe); lovely vanilla late in the nose.  Gorgeous!  Really spicy on the tongue, as pointed out in the last review...luscious candied fruits, light alcohol, and a small herbal component.  Medium to high carbonation, medium acidity, impressively balanced between the sugar and late acidic sourness.   Another glorious concoction from the folks at Het Anker, not quite up to the dOr or Kaiser, but still wonderful and necessary.
Hazy golden brown. This was a very enjoyable beer. The best part about it is its spiceyness. It has one of the best spice flavor I have had in a beer. Some alcohol is also tasted.

Bottle pours dirty golden, small frothish white head, lively carbonation, with average lacing.   Candi sugar, sweet malts, light alcohol, and slight apple/pear on the nose.   Sweet up front, a slight tang comes over the tongue, with a slight bitterness at the finish.   Getting some caramel and fruity flavors as well, apple with pear maybe.   Lively mouthfeel, decent body, but the flavor could be a bit more pronounced.   The 9% ABV doesnt come through on taste, but 1/4 through the bottle I can feel its warming effects.   Wished this one was a bit more flavorful.   Otherwise, pretty good.
Lively and refreshing citrus flavor.  Fizzy head with very light lacing.  Hoppy aroma, mildly yeasty...strong orange notes.  Extremely light on the palate with a dry finish.
