Sweet, caramel malt aroma. Spicy, mild hops. Golden body with fizzy white head that recedes to fine cover. Sweet malt, bitter orange, yeast, light spicy hops on the tongue. Smooth, easy to drink, effervescent. Very enjoyable. Bottle (sampled at Mondial 2004).

Clear dark golden with hints of red. Small long-lasting head. Lots of candied fruit in aroma; oranges, apples, and apricot. Lots of yeast. Malty and yeasty flavour with candied oranges. Quite spicy finish.

Sweet, fruity aroma -- typical of a tripel.  Nice big white foamy head, that leaves a decent amount of lacing. Golden color with a hint of copper and visible carbonation.
The flavor has orange and malts, definitely on the sweet side.  It has a nice amount of carbonation and a nice smooth aftertaste.  An enjoyable beer.

Hazy golden body with a thick, fluffy white head.  Sweet, fruity aroma of orange, banana, clove, yeasty bread and some nice esters.  Fairly full bodied for a Belgian.  The fruit and spice are the dominate forces here.  The yeasty fruit esters help these along for sure.  Orange and banana and strong as is the clove and other spices.  The finish is nice but leaves a little to be desired.  Another fine offering from Het Anker.

Nice warmblond beer with an orange reflection.The head is very fine and smooth.The smell off this beer is straightforward with impressions of ripe banana and orange marmelade.The taste is full and round and it has a fine bitterness.The alcohol touch in the end reminds me on a triple sec (Grand Marnier),but it also has a fine frechness in the end.I think that this beer is very drinkable and it has an original taste.
Amber color with a white head. The taste is fresh with fruity and slight citrusy notes. Has some spices and slight alcoholic notes.

33cl bottle  Pours hazey copper, very little head, but a thin collar does retain w/o lace.  To me this smells of wild blossom honey, sweet random floralness as well as carmelly malt.  Creamy drinking beer, quite smooth.  The flavor echoes the aroma, a dash of spicy hops, some bitterness and big malt, fades to just a bit of alcohol.  This brew is quite enjoyable and really reminds me of the Westmalle Tripel, of which I am a fan.

Not Aged!
 With the sediment in the glass, this Triple pours a murky golden brown, and a fluffy white head thick and luscious! 
 The aroma is full with huge notes of caramel, cotton candy, even some butterscotch very malty and full with brown sugar and plums. 
 Ok, so maybe Im a little buzzed from that last 750 of Allagash Triple but this so different! Far more toasty malt flavors, darker fruits, plums, apricots, raisins, even some stewed cabbage and corn-beef likeness but I think it might just be the black pepper similarities that Im equating here. 
 Sweet, with notes of rosemary and cove very nice! Its just so very different from the 24ozs of the Allagash!?theres SO much more brown sugar, and molasses, and far less citric fruit! 
The palate is so velvety  soft its like drinking satin! 

What more can I say This is the BEST BREWER in the world Im serious Im in Love with every one of the 4 brews Ive sampled!  No doubt Ill be cellaring a 4 pack of these 11.2oz bottles!

Bottled. 
Hazy golden, creamy head. Citrusy and malty with notes of lavender. Big malt sweetness.

Bottled.
Golden and hazy, with a creamy head.
A flowery citrus-aroma.
warm alko-feel with a fresh citrus-flavour.
Golden blond color.  Aroma of sweet fruit and pale malt.  The taste was the same.  Delightful and smooth from beginning to end.

Wow. Not a big fan of tripels but Maibockaddict and I shared this. 

Deep yellow in color. Excellent. 750 ml bottle.
Big fluffy white head. Dried fruit flavor. Big and malty. enjoyable.

750 ML corked bottle. Pours nice deep yellow, almost yellow-orange, with floaties and clear. Big fluffy white head. Aroma of candi (cotton?) and dried fruit. Big and malty flavor of vanilla, alcohol, white raisins, and candi. This is my second favorite triple to the triple Karimeliet...
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle: Golden and cloudy with a heavy head. Sweet and fruity aroma with a clear fresh taste. Good alcohol balance with clear notes of malt and yeast.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2014 One of the best examples of the Tripel style and a world classic beer that I wish I could afford to keep around more often.  +++  Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer pours a nice clear golden color with a large white head. The aroma is strong spiciness with a bit of fruit. A strong peppery spicy flavor with some sweetness and tartness added follows. Thick on the tongue. Mild spiciness lingers on the palate. A marvelous Triple and a world classic.

Attractive golden color with a nice fluffy off white head that is nicely retained.  Aroma is wonderful.  Figs, candy sugar and spices meld in a delicous melody of scents.  Flavor is complex.  Initial flavor is kinda harsh hairspray, then everything settles out and the finish is deliciously spicy.  Very nice mouth feel.  Very good Abbey Tripel.

Tap, at the brewery restaurant March 2004. Gold colour with good white head and good condition.  Excellently spiced nose with corriander, curacao and grain all apparent. Sweet and spicy in the mouth with a slightly flowery perfumed note on a good solid base of malt. Long sweet and spicy finish. Seems more subdued in bottle, but on tap was superb. I don't normally like tripels but this one impressed.

(Bottled, at the Helsinki Beer Festival 2004) Muddy, dark golden color, small head. Sourish, fruity aroma. Extremely fruity, slightly sweet orange peel / ginger flavor with honey. Medium to full-bodied, refreshing, slightly carbonated palate.

Hazy, deep golden ale with a large, frothy, white head. Thin, weepy lacing. The nose is of fuzzy fruit, leather, alcohol and a whisper of beef broth. Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Bold, sweet, alcoholic finish. Thanks to jbrus for the bottle.

Beer pours (in flute glass) a cloudy, lightly golden liquid with a small amount of off-white head that dissipates quickly to leave a thin film.  Aroma is of sweet fruit and citrus.  Flavor is of citrus, hoppy, and dry.  Sampled at 60 degrees Fahrenheit.

Hazy antique gold colour. Not much head, but very spritzy and prickly on the tongue once it gets into the mouth. Spirity nose with sweet malt and rich spices hovering in the background. Very sweet initial hit on the palate but backed up by cocktail of citrus fruits and balanced  by a clean yeasty acidity. Once the sweetness on the finish, a bone dry, sharp and flinty aftertaste, rather reminiscent of a young chablis lingers. Quite nice, but I wouldn't mind betting that this one would improve with age as the best before date was December 2005. Couldn't wait that long though. Bottle (33cl).

Lightly citrousy on the nose, a touch peppery.

Beautiful, hazy golden color with a big, fluffy white head consisting of a mountainous range of deeply packed little bubbles.   Bold flavor, big mouthfeel.  Sharply astringent, relaxed by a wave of sweet malt hopped just so.  Tart, nevertheless.  Fruity, leathery nature caries through to a dry finish.  Nice.

Cloudy dark yellow color with a huge small bubbled head that takes forever to settle.  Spicy aroma with light fruits (apple).  Full bodied and a bit fizzy on the tongue.  Ends lightly sweet with an oak wood flavor.  Long mellow ending.

Bottle. This beer formed a very large white head that was foamy with fine-small sized bubbles that were mostly lasting. The body was transparent, carbonated and yeasty with a yellow hue. The nose was fruity and alcohol. The flavor was of alcohol and somewhat bitter tasting. The mouthfeel was smooth and the lacing was fair.

This bottled brew poured a very large head of foamy finely sized off-white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lace.  The body is a carbonated transparent dark yellow color with a lot of floating brown yeat particles and the aroma is mildly malty with a bit of horseblanket.  The mouth feel is initially vinuous and it lingers into the finish with a mellowing of the vinuousness.  The flavor is vinuous with a mild malt and yeast flavor.

As with most tripels I've come into contact with, this has a head that sticks around for a little while.  Fair amount of carbonation.  A little cloudy.  Honey golden color.  Yeasty nose.  Dry and crisp.  Yeasty still.  Not as much in the ester, cloves, or banana flavor department.  Not sweet enough for me.
Great beer for a cold/ wet European night.  Medium amber color with a thick crisp head.  Alcohol is hidden quite well considering its level.  Very rich and spicy mouthfeel.

Bottle Conditioned. From BeersOfEurope. BBE Dec 2005.  Pale gold with thin foam head. Spicy orange liquor aroma. Dense tingly mouthfeel. Alcohol all over the place. I really should stop drinking these damn strong beers so young. Like a tingly, thinner, paler, spicier Barley Wine. I don't think I'm really a fan of Tripels.

Non-transparant brwon amber colour, with a little bit of bubbles.  Slightly brownish head.  Alcoholic, spicy (koriander) aroma.  The flavour is also alcoholish and spicy.  It starts bittery and ends very bitter.  A litte bit sweet too.

Deep golden colour with a beautiful and lasting white head. Impressive fruity aroma! Initial flavour is fruity too, then sweet and somewhat spicy. Sweet and bitter finish. Decent abbey trippel but too sweet imho.
Hazy amber color. Malt, alcohol, egg nose. Good strength, but too much alcohol; otherwise, just reasonable malt and a quite stronger bitterness.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2004 Very sweet with banana hints, Yeasty which comes from the top fermentation. Smooth, whopping alcohol taste will knock you on your ass if you're not careful.
Considerable head indeed.  Beautiful golden amber color with a sweet fruity and carmel aroma.  Smooth fruity taste, with some spice to the end.  Exelent drink for this late night.

Hazy burnt gold w/ beige head. Sweet, cotton-candyish, peachy aroma. Soft, velvety feel. Sweet but balanced yeasty flavour of peach, banana, cotton candy, bubble gum, toffee, & pepper. Warming finish.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2004 Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm. Pale golden, alittle hazy, no head. Aroma is yeasty, andfruity from grapes. Some bubbelgum. Flavor brings that fruity bubblegum-feeling and then turns into a quite bitter finish. Some nutty notes.

Orange amber body with a sturdy light tan head. Nose is sweet with candy sugar malt and alcohol and citrus notes. Sweet taste with more sugar and malt and white grapes and the tongue is surrounded with some effervescent bubbles in the mouthfeel and a light bitterness and dryness through the finish. Very good beer!

Colour between old gold and amber, slightly hazy (not cold haze); thick yellowish head. Alcoholic nose, liqueurish, sugar and preserved sugared fruit. Explicitly sweet and alcoholic taste, fruit sugar as preserved figs or 'marrons glacées', etc., sultana's. Somewhere a woody touch. Lots and lots of alcoholburn in the mouthfeel, very dry. A triple, yes, with with the G.C. fingerprint all over it. Again a good one, IMO, because it is an original interpretation. I dislike copycats.
Nice light aroma.  A very smooth tripel.  Not quite as outstanding as I was expecting, but a good brew all the same.

Bottled: Golden orange coloured. Lasting white head. Very spicy and fruity aroma. Light alcahol notes. Fruity, malty and sweet flavour. When the beer warms up, you can feel the alcahol on the lips. Has a pleasant fruity aftertaste with a little alcahol bite. Great beer.
Really nice triple.  Spicey, fruity - peachy, very light sourness, sweet and dry at the same time.  not too thick - just right.  Glowing yellow, good head and lacing.

Looks orange with a big fluffy head, hazy.  Smells like an orange, with just a hint of mustiness.  There is a definite bite on the palate.  Flavor is fairly complex, oranges, grape must, barnyard, and a pinch of salt, with a hoppy, bone dry finish.  Interesting, but not totally my thing in the end.

Aroma of sweet malt and a mild cinnamon. Standard ever present creamy belgian head. Flavor of malt, dark fruit, and mild cinnamon. No alcohol flavor detectable. Not the best tripel but a decent representation of what I expect the style to be.
Hazy gold color with a white head. Fruity aroma, citrusy. Spicy citrus flavor with a sweet finish. Some, but not much, lingering alcohol warmth. Enjoyed it.

Delicious stuff. Full of flavor and a terrific finish that ends in a wonderful, malty, brown sugar that goes on and on - much like I would enjoy drinking this - on and on. Quite good. Many thanks to the incredible Dougster.
Hazy golden coloured, big head. Fruity, spicy and a bit sweet, fairly complex. Good tripel.

On Tap in Paris. Citrus and fine bread aroma. Hazy golden appearance, white head, lace and more lace. Flavours of orange, pomegranate, grapefruit and pears. Very light bodied, good tongue tingle. Wonderful, and in a 1 Litre Glass!
Small white head leaving nice lace. Dark golden colour. Sweet, citrus, grass and alcohol. Doesn't live up to it's darker brother.

Cloudy golden in appearance with a sweet Belgiany aroma. Flavor is of spice and licorice. You can sense the alcohol, but you can't taste it or smell it as you'd expect at 9% ABV. I'm definitely a novice when it comes to Belgian beers but I do like this one - it's worth it's fairly high rating.
Hazy bronze colour. Huge head. Fruity aroma with a touch of tobacco. Fruity flavour with a touch of liquorice. A bit too much alcohol in the finish.

hazy golden with a white ring on the edge. aroma is juicy fruit and spicy as mother f'er! initially this beer is sweet as hell and it almost immediately numbs the tongue. there is only the slight presence of alcohol here. the aroma is just amazing as hell. also noticed a perfumey presence as it warms

This pours very nicely with a humongous puffy head.  Pale and golden in color, with an aroma that is slightly musky and extremely citrusy.  Very yeasty and doughy, with some fruit flavors coming through, dates and cinnamon mostly with some other flavors showing up as it warms.

Pours a golden hazy triple color with a large puffy white head & sticky lacing. Aroma is musky and sweet with lots of hops for a tripel. Flavor also reflects the hops in this but isn't as complex as expected. It's good and complete but just doesn't go the distance.
Slightly cloudy, gold color.  Big head was quick to disappear and  give way to an aroma of citrus and spice.  Fruity malt taste with a bit of sweetness that turns a litle more spicy as it warms.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2005 Hazy yellow, with a large white head.  Aroma of bread, honey and fruit.  Flavor is mostly sweet with some bitternes.  Finish is mildly dry.  Good Triple.
apricot, grapefruit aroma; golden fogginess, with little lace.  Very smooth  with perfect carbonation, sweet honey aftertaste.  Very nice.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Hazy yellow with small head and somelace. Spicy, banana, apricot, bubble gum aroma. Nice lightly sweet and bitter balance. Alcoholic feel yet smooth. Very nice Tripel.
Small white head, light cloudy amber.  Bubble gum, fruity aroma. Bitter, malt and hoppy at once. Complex. Nice roasted feel .Very good triple.

Vaporous honey sweet aroma. Alcohol, light brown sugar, bit of yeast, mild astringency. Hazy, some sediment in golden amber with white lacing creamy head. High carb in medium silky body. Taste is sweet to start, some hops. Followed by malt & yeast astringency - not chalky - and low bitterness. After is light alcoholic & watery bitter.

(Bottle) Slight alcohol nose with fruity ice cream. Orange body with little head. Burns the tip of the tongue. Caramelized fruit body with a lasting mild alcohol burn. So pleasant! Thanks Radek for brining this...
Rich golden hue, not much head. Fruity aroma, strawberries, pears. Medium sweet, candy sugar and kind of boozy, with citrus notes. Finish was smooth and lightly sugar coated.

Pours a redish golden. . . Large head, but it diminishes quickly and doesn't stick around.  Soft wheat  bread aroma, with loads of alcohol, bits of cracked pepper, and some fuzzy fruit - peach or maybe kiwi?  Fairly heavy raisin malt on the tongue, but a dry bitter finish with some orange, lemon, yeast, more pepper, and sugary alcohol.  This one was interesting and complex, but in the end the flavours didn't work too well for me.

Nice light malt aroma with hints of bread and other yeast aromas. Nice white head with fair lacing. A cloudy golden color.Heavy sweet flavors with slight bitter and sour falvors. Average finish with notes of alcohol. Medium bodied with a creamy/syrupy texture.
The aroma is sweet malty. The color is amber and it has a beutiful head. The flavor is very sweet malty with notes of fennel. The alcohol prickles the tongue and it has a good palate.

deep golden, big white head.  sweet caramel, yeasty, spicy and fruity(apple, raspberry) aroma.  the flavour is big with caramel apples, burnt sugar and alcohol.  a very rich mouthfeel, yet soft and subtle at the same time.  very nice.

Rich malt, tropical fruit and yeast in the aroma, some floral sweetness and spice, also a tinge of alcohol.  Medium golden color, particulate haze, and a large-bubbled, diminishing head.  Malty and sweet up front, followed by a blend of light citrus fruit before a rush of spicy, herbal, and nicely bittering hops.  Finish is lightly acidic, long and alcoholic, with a malty aftertaste featuring a few floral and honey notes.  Smooth, vinous mouthfeel and generous body.  Warming.  As this neared room temperature it really awoke, so to speak.  Very enjoyable Tripel.

Yeast, alcohol and faint citrus, and compelling aroma. Deep gold color with a medium to large pale white head. Slightly hazy. Flavor is malt, some hops, a background of alcohol, and a candy-like sweetness. Wonderful. MEdium to full body backs it all, followed by a finish of malt, alcohol, and more hints of citrus. Tail is all malt and alcohol. Wonderfully balanced throughout. Truly a world class beer!

Smell of yeast plus just a hint of lemon; the color is not as deep as in other tripels; typical tripel smoothness, but with slightly less intense taste; just the slightest bitterness in the aftertaste; I would rate this as a medium tripel, which still puts it way above most other types of beer

Mostly clear golden with a foamy head and some lace. Nose of bread and alcohol. A bit thin bodied for the style and with too much carbonation. Notes of earth and fruit (peach?). slightly piney hop presence in the finish. Not the best tripel but a damn  good one.
Spicy, citrus aroma. Orange, cloudy coloured. Good head. Sweet taste, spices, some malts.

75 cl. bottle. Dark Golden to overripe peach color.  Cream colored head. Wide sweeping aromas.  Licorice, mace, plumes, raisins, strawberries and petunias laces with white pepper. Flavors, thank heavens, do not completely match the aroma (I am not a licorice lover). Sweet spiced fruit bubblegum in the front. Middle with some pineapple, coriander and orange. Malt doesn't really come out until the finish - A merlot vinous quality with a hint of malt. A nice strong ale, but not high on my triple list.

Hazy amber w/ good head retention and lacing of white head.  Sweet malty aromaa w/ floral & earthy hop aromas.  Fruit and spice/clove aromas are very subdued.  Malty sweetness in the initial flavor then switches to hop dominant flavors but overall well balanced with a dry and bitter finish.  Aftertaste is fully hop and overall not a very complex flavor.  Alcohol is barely noticeable and is light bodied due to higer carbonation.  One of the more bitter tripels I've had and I have to say, it's not a favorite.  My preference is for malty tripels and this is not one of them. Drinkable in my book, but I would prefer not to have a bitter tripel.

Bottled at the Danish Beerfestival 2003:

A creamy and smooth triple. Nice laceworks. Lots of fruit and yeast. Very drinkable despite of the high ABV
Fruity, malty, chocolatey flavors. Very good. Beautiful color and head. Nice lace. Delicous. Not the best Tripel out there, but darned good.

Ah, yes, I will finish off tonight's Clemson beer fest (attendance = 1 [me]) with a Belgian Tripel. This one pours a nice golden color with a big white head. The head lingers for a while before finally dissipating into a thin layer on top of the beer. Strong aroma of fruits, most notably peaches, and yeasts, spices, and a touch of alcohol. Full body with lots of carbonation, the flavor is very fruity and yeasty with a strong alcohol presence. The finish is very sweet and spicy with a wonderful warmth from the alcohol. This is another magnificent brew from Belgium.
cloudy dark orange colour, dense creamy head and a nice lace, peach, hazelnut and yeasty, very smooth, full-bodied, dry finishing bitterness, bubblegum-like aftertaste with notes of alcohol

This is a whole meal full of bread, wine and cheese. If you close your eyes you can even feel the cellars where they kept the stores hundereds of years ago. The colour and creamy top gives you a really tempting impression. The ending is a bit too sweet for my taste.

A dark golden body holds up a white head that seems like liquid shouldnt be able to support, it is huge, thick, and never ending.  the aroma is a busy and begiuling one.  there is a creamy, orangy aroma with some spices thrown in for good measure.  I wish that i was able to culture this yeast when i tried it but i didnt have anything handy to do so.  the flavors this beer had were magnificent.  lots of tropical fruity flavors.  the body is somewhat thick and it coats the inside of the mouth yeilding a long lasting aftertaste.  the finish is a cross between sweetness and some spices, an extremely good balance.  i need to find a way to get more of this beer.

Another great belgian triple. Smoother and creamier than some. Caramel sweetness balanced with mild yeastiness and sourness. Banana bread came to mind at one point. Hoppy enough to give it bite and little spiciness.

The beer as it sets in the Triple glass is a ambiguous golden orange color, the head is portly in size, the color and off white, and the texture spumous, as the head decays, it leaves behind a fine covering of lace to seal off the glass. The nose is loaded with malt aromas, slightly plummish, crisp and fresh, the start is malt laden and lightly sweet. The top is middling in feel, the acidity biting, and the hops purposeful in their spicy bite, also vinous, tart and the aftertaste quite dry and long lasting.
Deep golden color, crisp mouthfeel. Bitter citrus character to it, and another phrase in my notes that I cannot read.

Cloudy orange body with medium off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, berry and orange, some spice.  Taste is kind of like a souped-up Wit, spicy malty.  Alcohol is evident in a mildly astringent aftertaste.
Hazy orange with huge head. Very bready nose with hints of fresh citrus. Massively carbonated with some light spices tickling my nose. Buttery and sugary at the end, no alcohol detected. Decent.

I like this brewery, and this is a nice triple.  Malty, as is characteristic of Het Anker's brews. Beautiful deep golden color, and the head is just the right size, hence the 5 for appearance.  Soft mouthfeel, and the alcohol is well integrated into the overall flavor.  A class act.

Poured a deep gold with an intense white belgian head. Aroma of clove, banana, and spice filled the glass. Flavor of belgian spice, candy, and alcohol dominated. Finished warm and alcoholic. Probably a little to alcoholic for my taste, but a decent belgian.

Sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden.
Deep golden with small creamy head. Fruity and sweet with notes of raspberries and spices. Soft maltiness and sugary finish.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 At pouring a huge head developed.  The blond color is excellent. Taste was a blend of hops and yeast.
9%ABV is decieving.  An excellent beverage for watching playoff football.  This was enjoyed again at Snowshoe in Febriuary 2010.  Justin and Celeste brought some beer to taste.  The Saison also was outstanding.  This ale poured with a huge head and was just as good as the last one.  I did tatse some pears and some sweetness.  I am keeping the same score as last one.
on tap: This surprised me - wasnt expecting such a great blend yeast and hops, both in the nose and flavor. Typical tripel spiciness in the middle. Complex with a great body and balance.
Fresh lemon and orange aroma. Dark golden color, white head, good lace. Very citrus, sweet, alcohol well hidden, starts off with lemon flavors and turn orange. Long hoppy, little dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2003 Frirst raiting: 4.4: Fruity orange hops nose. Orange body with a medium frothy head. Soft carbonation. Spicey - yumm; addings after the newley rating: grape nose. Tasted alos koriander, roses and yeast. Great one.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 Blond beer with a medium creamy head. Very unusual aroma with a hint fruit. Not strong, just different. It is some spice  I feel I should know. The taste is hop, spice and fruit. Slightly sweet start with a bitter finish. An interesting beer.
Big head, banana nose, slightly hazy orangish gold body. More fruit than spice, with some bite in the front of the mouth and a smooth finish. The 9% ABV isnt very noticeable.
Stewed apple with spices and a touch of banana in the flavour.  Not as bitter/dry as many other tripels but the difference is what makes this such a good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2003 Re-rate, 1/25/03.  Still has an amazing nose, but the taste is very, very good in my second sample.  Very spicy and zippy.  Finish hangs around, nice, tasty, sugary ending to this brew.  Original rating:  Wondrous nose, spicy and fruity.  Flavor starts quite nice, plenty of banana and zippiness, but the finish sort of disappears.  Very dry, doesn't have any ending zing.
Big thick head, cloudy with heavy carbonation. Great aroma. Not the best, but damn good.
peanut nougat dipped in kero
I am not big on tripels but this is definitely worth trying again and it is by far the best tripel i have ever had. very well balanced and dry.
Very good tripel......even though I dont favor the style.
UPDATED: JAN 24, 2003 Smooth ale alcohol well hidden.  Clean and crisp flavor.  A nice balanced taste

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2008 Malty, raisinny aroma. Sweet, malty, raisinny, peppery taste. Long peppery bitter finish. From the bottle it has a flowery, honeyish aroma. Tap: unfiltered. Cafe Morshuis Albergen. Lemonaroma, initial lemon and vanilla flavor. After that loads of hops. Strong long lasting hoppy aftertaste. The 9% ABV is not noticed at all. Pity the beer was served too cold.
Bottle, 3 years old: Vinous aroma with remaining flowery hops and orange. Fusel alcohols in the flavor, that is becoming like old brandy. Vinous, notes of sherry. Alcoholic, but still satisfyingly balanced. Nice!
after the initial shock of the bad vodka fumes emanating from my glass, i liked this one. tastes uncannily like satay chicken. VERy coriander heavy, quite salty and a little bit tart. soft textured.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2015 Rerate: Bottle from Mitra Bunnik, BB Febr 2017, large sample. Clear golden color, huge rocky slight off-white head. Aroma is quite sweet for a triple, lots of orange peel, slight coriander, slight peppery yeast. Soft bitterness in taste, again lots of orange peel, quite some sweetness. Actually getting close to Karmeliet Tripel with its loads of orange peel and being on the fruity sweet side for a tripel. Silly I havent tried this one before a lot as Im a huge fan of Karmeliet. Lovely stuff. Upgrading to 3.9.
Original rate from 2002: Decent triple by Brouwerij het Anker, though nothing special. Tasted like the Triple Toison dOr, also from Het Anker. 3.4

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2015 750mL bottle (April 13, 2015 bottling).

Head is initially large, frothy, white, fully lasting.
Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with a strong note of coriander, other notes of gum, dried pineapple.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Beautiful appearance, nice flavor balance and mouthfeel, but just too much coriander in the nose...its like Tripel Karmeliet in that regard. This would probably be a 4+ tripel if it was unspiced.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2003 Pretty strong. The alcohol is very conspicuous. It reminds me very much of the Bornem Triple. Maybe this is a touch more elegant.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2014 Potent coriander and a thick floral bouquet serve as a bed for some light herbs and cantaloupAn alcohol whip lashes in tandem with some hop bitternessA Tripel on the sweet side of things, but then again that is to be expected from these masters of spice and sugars

Faintly hazy gold orange with smallish short lasting yellow head. Luscious fruity hops, spices and honey, with some candy malt aroma. Medium -large body. Strong nicely balanced, bitter-sweet palate hiding the 9% very well. Softer dry bitter refreshing finish and long fruity sweet burp. Recommended to all lovers of strong Belgians - go and get yourself some.
It wasa difficult for me to find this beer in Brussels,when I did, found it hoppy and balanced especially for a beer of such strength.

very nice tripel.
straw gold colour, white bubbly head that left some dense lacing.
a good bit hoppier than most tripels  but still balanced.
has some surprising wit like spice tastes.
hides the 9% alcohol well.
